title: Kingswood, New South Wales
text:
Kingswood is a <a href="suburb">suburb</a> in <a href="Greater%20Western%20Sydney">western</a> <a href="Sydney">Sydney</a>, in the state of <a href="New%20South%20Wales">New South Wales</a> in <a href="Australia">Australia</a>. It is 52 kilometres west of the <a href="Sydney%20central%20business%20district">Sydney central business district</a>, in the <a href="Local%20government%20in%20Australia">local government area</a> of the <a href="City%20of%20Penrith">City of Penrith</a>. There are various other locations within the state of <a href="New%20South%20Wales">New South Wales</a> that are also called Kingswood, and is often confused with the nearby suburb of <a href="Kingswood%20Park%2C%20New%20South%20Wales">Kingswood Park</a>.
History.
Kingswood was named after the family of Governor <a href="Philip%20Gidley%20King">Philip Gidley King</a>, who owned land in the area which was originally heavily forested. In 1881, the area was known as Crossroads for the intersection of the Great Western Highway and The Northern Road (now Parker Street). The name was changed to Kingswood on 2 August 1887. "Cross Roads West" Post Office opened on 20 April 1887 and was renamed "Kingswood" in August 1887.
The land was used for farming and subdivision began after the railway came through in 1862, although the Kingswood siding did not open until 1887.
The NSW State Archives and Reading Room (formerly known as Western Sydney Records Repository), where NSW public sector bodies' records are stored, is located on O'Connell Street, Kingswood.
Population.
According to the <a href="Census%20in%20Australia%232016">2016 census</a> of Population, there were 9,301 people in Kingswood.
Transport.
<a href="Kingswood%20railway%20station%2C%20Sydney">Kingswood Railway Station</a> is on the <a href="North%20Shore%20%26amp%3B%20Western%20Line">North Shore & Western Line</a> of the <a href="Sydney%20Trains">Sydney Trains</a> network.
Schools.
Government
Private
Governance.
At a local government level, Kingswood is part <a href="Penrith%20City%20Council">Penrith City Council</a>, with the suburb divided into all three wards. At the state level, it is part of the <a href="Electoral%20district%20of%20Penrith">Electoral district of Penrith</a>, represented by the Liberal Party's <a href="Stuart%20Ayres">Stuart Ayres</a>. Federally, it is part of the <a href="Division%20of%20Lindsay">Division of Lindsay</a>, represented by <a href="Liberal%20Party%20of%20Australia">Liberal Party</a> <a href="Melissa%20McIntosh">Melissa McIntosh</a>.
Churches.
In 1897, four blocks of <a href="Crown%20land">Crown land</a> were given to the residents of Kingswood for a Church and <a href="Cemetery">Cemetery</a> (later not required due to the dedication of <a href="Penrith%2C%20New%20South%20Wales">Penrith</a> General Cemetery). The Church was completed in 1898, the contractor was Jack Melville with ironwork provided by local blacksmith James Wainwright. The western porch was added later. Opened in 1898, the Church was not <a href="consecrated">consecrated</a> until 1959. A new <a href="Sunday%20school">Sunday school</a> hall was completed in 1958 (now demolished).
